Description: An hollow terracotta upper-body fragment of Phthonos, the personification of Envy: a male with grotesque features and bald, with his head thrown back, and strangling himself with both hands. There was probably a vertical wound in his abdomen. He wears bracelets and armlets. Holes are bored into his ears: perhaps firing-vents. A pierced suspension-lug was applied behind the neck. The back is modelled. The break has been smoothed below in modern times to enable it to stand. Two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with a brown surface. Traces of a dressing coloured pink.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Greville J. Chester. Roman, probably third century AD. Comparanda: Close (head only): Grmek and Gourevitch 1998: 199, fig. 145, from Smyrna, described as Hellenistic = Besques 1971: pl. 309a, regarded as a mime. Other terracotta representations of Phthonos from Egypt: Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, no. 1982.901, from 'Mansheer', the Greek City of Ptolemais; Bonacasa 1997: 100, fig. 5, with an Evil Eye on its head; Breccia 1930: no. 402 and pl. xxxi:2 and 5; Dunbabin and Dickie 1983: pl. 3b; Vogt 1924: pl. cv:6.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3384)
Acquisition name: Purchased from: Rev Greville John Chester
